text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Jordanian press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Jordan will propose plans worth 3.70 billion dinars ($5.22 billion) at the Cairo Middle East economic summit in November. Plans cover projects in industry, minerals, communications, tourism and water sectors.
- French President Chirac to get warm welcome when he delivers speech to parliament on Thursday. Opposition groups appreciate the positive statements from Paris on the Middle East.
- Kabariti calls for 100,000 dinars to support sports clubs for refugees.
- Central tender agency says it will issue tender within two days for new loading platform worth 25 million dinars ($35.3 million) at Jordan's Aqaba port.
- Doctors say they won some of their rights in talks with the government. Committee will meet today to cancel decision to stop work.
- Speaker of Austrian parliament arrives in Jordan on Wednesday for three-day visit.
- Minister of Supply Munir Sobar says government considering cancelling import duties on sugar, rice and other commodities which the private sector may want to import, including corn and fodder.
- Arab Organisation for Human Rights in Jordan alleges human rights violations, including curbs on freedom of expression. Ex-detainees claim torture.
- Central Bank governor Fariz says small Arab capital markets encourage capital flight.
- Jordanian economist says inflation will rise to eight percent because of food price increases.
